detailed_description: In today's digital age, financial fraud has become an increasingly prevalent and costly issue for businesses and consumers. As technology and AI continue to improve, fraudsters develop more creative and sophisticated attacks. This constant evolution requires fraud prevention solutions to continuously adapt and improve their detection capabilities.
core_problems_solved: Prevent fraudulent transactions
Reduce false positives in fraud detection
Detect and mitigate social engineering and phishing attacks
Identify and prevent deepfake impersonations
Manage risks associated with real-time payments
Address first-party fraud scenarios

example_companies.name: Carefull
example_companies.description: Provides financial safety and monitoring for caretakers and their families, focusing on preventing suspicious payments and deposits, setting up bill payments, monitoring credit and identity, and offering trusted access control to family members.

example_companies.name: Sublime Security
example_companies.description: Assists security teams in monitoring inbound emails, blocking domains, and triaging phishing attacks for various enterprises.

example_companies.name: Doppel
example_companies.description: Offers anti-phishing and brand protection by monitoring email, applications, and social media to detect impersonations.

example_companies.name: DuckDuckGoose
example_companies.description: Provides scoring on tampered images and AI detection, assisting in identifying fake IDs during account onboarding.

example_companies.name: Reality Defender
example_companies.description: Analyzes speech patterns or video calls in real-time to detect deepfake content.

example_companies.name: Unit21
example_companies.description: Aggregates data insights in their consortium to help members share protected/anonymous data, screen customers for reported fraud, and customize workflows based on risk tolerance.

example_companies.name: Effectiv
example_companies.description: Provides a platform solution with payment fraud detection for real-time payments as a core feature.

business_model_focus: B2B SaaS, Enterprise
market_opportunity: With consumers and businesses losing a record $12.5 billion to online fraud in 2023 and financial institutions spending approximately $500 billion annually on identity verification and fraud prevention, there is a significant market opportunity for innovative solutions in this space.

detailed_description: Latin America is undergoing a fintech revolution, particularly in cross-border payments and money movement. With a significant unbanked population and rising digital adoption, there's immense potential for innovative solutions. Key areas include remittance services, B2B payment platforms, FX and treasury solutions, blockchain and crypto applications, and open banking APIs. These innovations aim to reduce costs, increase transaction speeds, and enhance financial inclusion across the region.
core_problems_solved: High costs and delays in cross-border transactions
Limited access to financial services for the unbanked
Complexities in currency exchange and treasury operations
Lack of interoperability among financial systems
Regulatory challenges in cross-border compliance

example_companies.name: EBANX
example_companies.description: Specializes in cross-border payment solutions, enabling global businesses to accept local payment methods from Latin American consumers, facilitating international e-commerce transactions across the region.

example_companies.name: Belvo
example_companies.description: Provides open banking APIs that enable fintechs to access and interpret user financial data from banks and fiscal institutions.

example_companies.name: Bitso
example_companies.description: A cryptocurrency platform that facilitates cross-border payments using blockchain technology.

example_companies.name: Kushki
example_companies.description: Offers advanced analytics to optimize payment routing and reduce transaction costs.

example_companies.name: Prometeo
example_companies.description: Provides open banking APIs that connect to various financial institutions across LATAM.

business_model_focus: B2B SaaS, B2C, Enterprise
market_opportunity: The cross-border payments industry exceeds $200 trillion globally. Reducing friction in international trade could boost GDP by $250 billion and save global businesses $100 billion. In LATAM, increasing financial inclusion to developed countries' levels could boost GDP by up to 30%, with fintech solutions potentially bringing 30-50 million unbanked adults into the formal financial system by 2025.

detailed_description: Identic AI represents an emerging technological paradigm that combines advanced AI capabilities with identity verification, authentication, and management specifically tailored for financial services. This technology integrates biometrics, document verification, behavioral analysis, and fraud detection to create more secure, efficient, and seamless identity management systems for financial institutions. As financial services become increasingly digital, robust identity verification and management are critical to institutional success.
core_problems_solved: Enhance security in financial transactions
Streamline customer onboarding processes
Ensure compliance with regulatory requirements
Prevent fraud through advanced detection methods
Maintain user privacy during identity verification

example_companies.name: Onfido
example_companies.description: Provides AI-powered identity verification and authentication solutions, enabling businesses to verify users' identities using a combination of document verification and facial biometrics.

example_companies.name: Jumio
example_companies.description: Offers AI-driven identity verification services, including document verification, biometric authentication, and AML screening, to help businesses reduce fraud and meet compliance requirements.

example_companies.name: Socure
example_companies.description: Utilizes AI and machine learning to provide real-time digital identity verification and fraud detection solutions, focusing on reducing identity fraud and improving customer onboarding.

example_companies.name: Trulioo
example_companies.description: Provides global identity verification services through AI-powered solutions, enabling businesses to verify identities and comply with KYC/AML regulations across various countries.

example_companies.name: Auth0
example_companies.description: Offers a flexible, drop-in solution to add authentication and authorization services to applications, enhancing security and simplifying identity management for developers.

business_model_focus: B2B SaaS, Enterprise
market_opportunity: The global digital identity market is projected to reach over $70 billion by 2027, with financial services as the largest vertical. Financial institutions spend approximately $500 billion annually on identity verification and fraud prevention, and $300 billion on KYC/AML compliance. The 76% increase in digital banking adoption further accelerates the demand for remote verification solutions.

detailed_description: Agentic AI represents a transformative shift in the financial services industry, characterized by autonomous decision-making and adaptive learning capabilities. This advanced form of AI enables financial institutions to enhance efficiency, accuracy, and personalization across various operations, including trading, risk management, customer service, and compliance. By processing vast amounts of data in real-time, AI agents can identify patterns and anomalies, making complex decisions with minimal human intervention.
core_problems_solved: Automating complex trading strategies across multiple asset classes and markets
Enhancing risk assessment and mitigation to prevent fraud and cyber attacks
Providing tailored investment advice and portfolio management at scale
Ensuring real-time compliance with evolving financial regulations
Assessing creditworthiness using alternative data sources and adapting to changing economic conditions

example_companies.name: Kavout
example_companies.description: Utilizes AI to provide quantitative investment strategies and insights, offering AI-driven stock rankings and portfolio management tools.

example_companies.name: Ayasdi
example_companies.description: Offers AI-driven risk management solutions, helping financial institutions detect anomalies and manage compliance more effectively.

example_companies.name: Betterment
example_companies.description: Provides automated, personalized investment advice and portfolio management services through its robo-advisor platform.

example_companies.name: Hummingbird
example_companies.description: Develops AI-powered compliance solutions to help financial institutions detect and report suspicious activities, streamlining regulatory processes.

example_companies.name: Zest AI
example_companies.description: Utilizes machine learning to enhance credit underwriting, offering dynamic credit scoring models that consider a wide range of data points.

business_model_focus: B2B SaaS, Enterprise Solutions
market_opportunity: The global financial services AI market is projected to reach $190 billion by 2025, driven by the need for operational efficiency, enhanced risk management, and personalized financial services. Financial institutions face potential losses of up to $5 trillion annually due to fraud and cyber attacks, highlighting the critical role of AI in mitigating these risks. The wealth management industry, valued at $89 trillion globally, stands to benefit from AI agents that can provide tailored investment advice and portfolio management at scale.

detailed_description: AI is transforming historically human-led professional services sectors by automating judgment-based, knowledge-heavy workflows once thought impossible to scale. Enabled by improvements in foundation models, reasoning capabilities, and domain-specific data tooling, AI systems are evolving from passive copilots to active coworkers. This shift is especially relevant in industries constrained by workforce shortages, aging talent, or margin pressure. As AI tools specialize, we see an opportunity for vertical platforms and smaller models to outperform general LLMs, unlocking enterprise data moats in sectors like accounting, underwriting, legal services, marketing, architecture, and engineering.
core_problems_solved: Manual, time-consuming knowledge work
Shortage of skilled professionals in key industries
Siloed or offline enterprise data that limits automation
Low productivity in white-collar service workflows
Rising cost structures and margin compression
Difficulty scaling expertise and decision consistency

example_companies.name: Higharc
example_companies.description: Provides AI-powered home design automation, enabling builders and designers to create customized home plans efficiently.

example_companies.name: Pylon Lending
example_companies.description: Offers AI-powered underwriting solutions, streamlining the lending process and enhancing risk assessment.

example_companies.name: Keyway
example_companies.description: Utilizes AI for dynamic underwriting in real estate, optimizing property valuations and investment strategies.

example_companies.name: Fermat
example_companies.description: Delivers AI-generated marketing content and strategy recommendations tailored to user segments, automating brand messaging and campaign execution.

example_companies.name: Harvey
example_companies.description: Develops AI tools for legal services, assisting with contract analysis, legal research, and document drafting.

business_model_focus: B2B SaaS, Enterprise Solutions
market_opportunity: Professional services account for over 13% of US GDP, yet many workflows remain manual due to unstructured data and reliance on human expertise. AI has the potential to transform up to 30% of white-collar roles, unlocking massive efficiency gains and new service models. Industries facing structural workforce issues—like accounting, construction, or law—present near-term opportunities, especially when paired with proprietary datasets and specialized models tailored to each domain.

detailed_description: The insurance industry, a cornerstone of economic stability, is undergoing significant transformation driven by technological advancements, evolving consumer needs, and emerging risks. With the U.S. Gross Written Premiums (GWP) reaching $2.1 trillion in 2023 and projected to surpass $3 trillion by 2027, there is a substantial opportunity for innovation. Key areas of focus include developing new insurance products for AI applications, addressing climate-related risks, enhancing client interactions through AI, intelligent underwriting and decision-making, automating claims processes, and leveraging new data models and providers to improve risk assessment and operational efficiency.
core_problems_solved: Developing insurance products to cover liabilities associated with AI applications
Providing coverage for losses resulting from climate-related events
Enhancing customer engagement and service through AI-driven interactions
Improving underwriting accuracy and efficiency using intelligent systems
Streamlining claims processing through automation
Utilizing advanced data models to better assess and price risk

example_companies.name: Vouch
example_companies.description: Offers tailored business insurance solutions for startups and small businesses, addressing unique risks faced by these entities.

example_companies.name: Future Family
example_companies.description: Provides fertility financing and insurance solutions, making fertility treatments more accessible and affordable.

example_companies.name: Cape Analytics
example_companies.description: Utilizes AI to provide property intelligence for insurance carriers, enhancing underwriting and risk assessment.

example_companies.name: Snapsheet
example_companies.description: Offers claims management solutions that streamline and automate the claims process for insurers.

example_companies.name: Sure
example_companies.description: Provides digital insurance infrastructure, enabling companies to embed insurance products seamlessly into their offerings.

business_model_focus: B2B SaaS, Enterprise, InsurTech
market_opportunity: With the U.S. insurance market projected to exceed $3 trillion in GWP by 2027, driven by factors such as rising social inflation and reinsurance rates, there is a significant opportunity for innovative solutions that modernize insurance products and processes. The growth of the Excess and Surplus (E&S) market, reaching $115 billion in direct written premiums in 2023, highlights the demand for tailored insurance solutions addressing emerging risks.

thesis_name: The Great Wealth Shift: Transforming Financial Legacies
detailed_description: The United States is on the brink of an unprecedented intergenerational wealth transfer, with an estimated $84 to $124 trillion set to change hands over the next two decades. This monumental shift will primarily see Baby Boomers and the Silent Generation passing their wealth to Gen X, Millennials, and Gen Z. This transition is poised to reshape sectors such as financial services, insurance, real estate, and technology, presenting significant opportunities for businesses that facilitate and optimize this wealth transfer.
key_concepts: AI and automation in wealth management
digital identity and security for wealth transfers
core_problems_solved: Facilitating seamless and secure intergenerational wealth transfers
Enhancing financial literacy and engagement among younger generations
Integrating advanced technologies to modernize traditional wealth management practices
Addressing the evolving preferences of Millennials and Gen Z in financial services
Mitigating risks associated with large-scale asset transfers

example_companies.name: Trust & Will
example_companies.description: Provides digital estate planning solutions, making it easier for individuals to create wills and trusts online.

example_companies.name: Envestnet
example_companies.description: Offers integrated wealth management technology and services, enabling financial advisors to better serve their clients.

example_companies.name: Plaid
example_companies.description: Provides a data network that powers the fintech tools millions of consumers rely on to live healthier financial lives.

example_companies.name: Betterment
example_companies.description: An online investment company offering robo-advising and cash management services.

example_companies.name: Wealthfront
example_companies.description: Provides automated, software-based investment and banking services.

business_model_focus: B2C, B2B2C, SaaS
market_opportunity: With $84 to $124 trillion expected to be transferred over the next two decades, there is a significant opportunity for companies that can facilitate efficient, secure, and user-friendly wealth transfer processes. This includes innovations in estate planning, digital wealth advisory services, real estate inheritance solutions, and platforms that cater to the financial preferences of younger generations.

detailed_description: The integration of artificial intelligence (AI) into drug discovery is revolutionizing the pharmaceutical industry by enhancing efficiency, reducing costs, and accelerating timelines. Traditional drug development is a lengthy and expensive process, often taking 10-15 years and costing approximately $2.3 billion to bring a single new drug to market. AI addresses these challenges by optimizing various stages of drug development, including target identification, lead optimization, and clinical trial design. The convergence of technological advancements, increased data availability, and improved computational power has paved the way for AI-driven innovations in this field.
core_problems_solved: Reducing the time and cost associated with drug development
Improving accuracy in target identification and validation
Enhancing the efficiency of lead optimization processes
Streamlining clinical trial design and patient recruitment
Integrating multi-omics data for comprehensive disease understanding

example_companies.name: Insitro
example_companies.description: Utilizes machine learning and high-throughput biology to model disease and accelerate drug discovery.

example_companies.name: Exscientia
example_companies.description: Combines AI and experimental approaches to design novel drug candidates with improved efficacy.

example_companies.name: BenevolentAI
example_companies.description: Employs AI to analyze biomedical data and discover new therapeutic targets.

example_companies.name: Atomwise
example_companies.description: Leverages AI for structure-based drug design to predict the binding affinity of small molecules.

example_companies.name: Recursion Pharmaceuticals
example_companies.description: Integrates AI with automated, high-content biology to discover treatments across various diseases.

business_model_focus: B2B, partnerships with pharmaceutical companies, SaaS
market_opportunity: The global AI in drug discovery market is projected to reach $3.9 billion by 2027, driven by the need to reduce drug development costs and timelines. The adoption of AI technologies offers the potential to streamline processes, improve success rates, and bring novel therapies to market more efficiently.

detailed_description: Artificial Intelligence (AI), data analytics, and personalized medicine are revolutionizing oncology care, aiming to improve patient outcomes, reduce treatment costs, and enhance overall care quality. With cancer being the second-leading cause of death worldwide, the need for innovative solutions is urgent. AI-powered technologies are advancing early detection, drug discovery, clinical trial optimization, and personalized treatment planning. The explosion of multi-dimensional oncology data, including genomics, imaging, and clinical records, is fueling AI applications in cancer treatment.
core_problems_solved: Improving early cancer detection and diagnosis accuracy
Accelerating the development of novel cancer therapeutics
Enhancing patient matching and trial design for clinical trials
Optimizing treatment plans based on multi-modal patient data
Reducing preventable hospitalizations through AI-driven care coordination

example_companies.name: Tempus
example_companies.description: Develops AI-driven precision medicine solutions by integrating clinical and molecular data to guide oncology treatments.

example_companies.name: Paige
example_companies.description: Uses AI for cancer detection and classification in pathology imaging, enhancing diagnostic accuracy.

example_companies.name: Owkin
example_companies.description: Combines federated learning with AI to develop predictive models for cancer treatment and drug discovery.

example_companies.name: ConcertAI
example_companies.description: Utilizes AI and real-world evidence to optimize clinical trials and oncology research.

example_companies.name: Flatiron Health
example_companies.description: Develops oncology-focused software solutions and real-world evidence platforms to enhance cancer care.

business_model_focus: B2B SaaS, Biotech Partnerships, Enterprise Healthcare
market_opportunity: The U.S. oncology market exceeded $200 billion in 2023 and continues to grow rapidly due to increasing cancer prevalence, treatment advancements, and AI integration. AI-driven precision medicine solutions could improve cancer survival rates while significantly reducing healthcare costs.

detailed_description: Commerce is entering a new era powered by AI agents, real-time personalization, autonomous supply chains, and intelligent procurement systems. This evolution builds on decades of transformation—from early marketplaces and omnichannel platforms to mobile and social commerce. As large language models and agents mature, we anticipate a generational shift toward infrastructure that makes commerce more contextual, efficient, and adaptive. This includes dynamic personalization engines, full-stack shopping agents, automated ad platforms, supply chain intelligence, and systems that support recommerce and sustainable trade. These systems will replace fragmented legacy stacks and enable seamless shopping, logistics, and marketing experiences orchestrated by AI.
core_problems_solved: Inefficient and generic consumer experiences
Manual and siloed inventory and procurement workflows
Inability to optimize ad spend and personalize marketing at scale
Overstock and unsold inventory due to poor demand prediction
Lack of infrastructure to support autonomous agents in transactions
Environmental waste from linear consumption models

example_companies.name: Fermat
example_companies.description: Provides infrastructure for dynamic, personalized shopping across the customer lifecycle, enabling embedded commerce experiences at scale.

example_companies.name: Airial
example_companies.description: Delivers AI-powered trip planning tools that unbundle travel marketplaces and provide personalized experiences for consumers and agencies.

example_companies.name: Dynamic Yield
example_companies.description: Uses machine learning to deliver real-time, individualized recommendations and experiences across web and mobile interfaces.

example_companies.name: Coupa
example_companies.description: Optimizes enterprise procurement and supply chain decisions using AI-driven insights, helping companies manage vendors and costs.

example_companies.name: ThredUp
example_companies.description: A secondhand apparel marketplace advancing the circular economy through scalable resale infrastructure and consumer resale-as-a-service tools.

business_model_focus: B2B SaaS, Marketplaces, Embedded Commerce, Platform Infrastructure
market_opportunity: The global e-commerce market is expected to reach $6.5 trillion by 2025, with increasing complexity and consumer expectations requiring intelligent, adaptive infrastructure. Companies that enable AI-native commerce—from personalization and procurement to recommence and voice-first agents—will define the next generation of commerce platforms. Circular economy platforms alone represent a $250B+ opportunity in excess inventory management, while supply chain optimization can yield 15–25% margin improvements for enterprise clients. Meanwhile, Gen Z and Alpha consumers are driving demand for immersive, gamified, and agent-assisted shopping experiences, signaling a broader interface and behavioral shift in the future of commerce.

thesis_name: AI's Unlock in Interactive Content and Gaming
detailed_description: AI is revolutionizing how digital experiences are created, distributed, and consumed—especially in gaming and interactive content. The convergence of generative AI, real-time game engines, and accessible creation tools is enabling a new era of creativity and engagement. This shift empowers both creators and players, blurring the lines between consumers and developers while unlocking novel forms of storytelling, gameplay, and monetization.
core_problems_solved: Lower barriers to entry for game and content creation
Enable scalable content generation for games and media
Enhance engagement through personalized and dynamic experiences
Empower creators with AI-assisted tools
Increase monetization opportunities for UGC platforms
Streamline game development workflows

example_companies.name: Inworld AI
example_companies.description: Builds AI-powered NPCs with human-like memory, motivations, and personalities to make games more immersive and responsive.

example_companies.name: Scenario
example_companies.description: Allows game developers to generate custom, style-consistent game assets using generative AI.

example_companies.name: Promethean AI
example_companies.description: Offers a creative assistant for worldbuilding in virtual environments, helping artists and designers populate 3D spaces faster.

example_companies.name: Didimo
example_companies.description: Provides a platform for generating lifelike 3D avatars from a single photo, usable in games, virtual worlds, and digital interactions.

business_model_focus: B2B tools, platform infrastructure, UGC platforms
market_opportunity: With over 3 billion gamers worldwide and the rise of the creator economy, the convergence of AI and gaming presents a massive opportunity to redefine how interactive content is built and monetized. The demand for scalable, AI-assisted creation tools is growing across gaming, entertainment, and immersive media platforms.

thesis_name: Providers of the Future: Specialty Care & Concierge
detailed_description: The healthcare system is struggling to meet the needs of aging populations and patients with chronic or specialized conditions. Long wait times for specialist appointments, fragmented care coordination, and a lack of scalable infrastructure have created an opening for next-generation providers. 'Providers of the Future' combines tech-enabled specialty care, concierge medicine, and home-based monitoring to deliver personalized, proactive, and accessible care experiences. These models empower both physicians—many of whom are frustrated with legacy systems—and patients, who increasingly demand convenience, responsiveness, and transparency.
core_problems_solved: Limited access to in-demand specialists, especially in endocrinology, cardiology, and geriatrics
Long wait times and lack of transparency in scheduling and medical records
Inadequate home care solutions for aging populations
Physician burnout and misalignment with current healthcare workflows
Fragmented care journeys across diagnosis, treatment, and follow-up
Out-of-pocket care not optimized for user experience or value
business_model_focus: Direct-to-consumer (D2C) concierge platforms, B2B2C provider enablement, remote care tools, self-pay specialty practices
market_opportunity: An aging population, physician shortages, and patient frustration with the status quo are driving demand for new care delivery models. The U.S. specialty care market alone exceeds $300B, while concierge medicine and cross-border medical tourism are rapidly expanding. With the right tech stack and service model, startups can meaningfully improve outcomes, empower caregivers, and unlock massive economic value in healthcare delivery.

detailed_description: The CFO's role is evolving from traditional financial oversight to a strategic partner driving business growth. This shift necessitates a modern tech stack that enhances cash flow management, automates financial operations, and provides real-time insights. Emerging solutions focus on intelligent cash management, risk mitigation, and automation of financial processes, catering to the needs of SMBs and large enterprises alike.
core_problems_solved: Enhancing yield on idle cash for SMBs
Automating currency risk management for global transactions
Streamlining ledgering and reconciliation processes
Improving accuracy and efficiency in financial operations
Providing real-time financial insights for strategic decision-making

example_companies.description: Provides usage-based billing solutions for SaaS companies, enabling flexible and scalable pricing models.

example_companies.name: Sequence
example_companies.description: Offers billing infrastructure for modern software companies, supporting complex pricing and billing workflows.

example_companies.name: Stage
example_companies.description: Delivers financial planning tools that integrate with existing systems to provide real-time budgeting and forecasting.

example_companies.name: Octane
example_companies.description: Provides financial operations software designed to automate and streamline billing and revenue recognition processes.

example_companies.name: m3tr
example_companies.description: Offers tools for managing subscription billing and revenue operations, tailored for SaaS businesses.

example_companies.description: Provides financial analytics and planning solutions, helping businesses make data-driven financial decisions.

business_model_focus: B2B SaaS, Enterprise
market_opportunity: The global market for CFO software solutions is experiencing significant growth, driven by the increasing need for automation, real-time analytics, and efficient financial operations. As businesses seek to optimize cash flow and manage financial risks, there is a substantial opportunity for innovative solutions that cater to the evolving role of the CFO.

thesis_name: Physical AI: Robotic Applications and Foundational Infra
detailed_description: The robotics industry is reaching a critical inflection point as hardware advances converge with breakthroughs in AI, perception, and simulation. Yet, the majority of robotics startups and engineering teams still face immense friction in building, deploying, and scaling robotic systems. The next wave of opportunity lies in the foundational infrastructure that makes robotics development faster, safer, and more scalable. From simulation and control stacks to modular development platforms and robotics-native dev tools, these technologies are unlocking faster iteration cycles, lowering barriers to entry, and expanding robotics into new sectors. As robotics moves from R&D labs into real-world logistics, manufacturing, healthcare, and more, infrastructure companies will power the transition.
core_problems_solved: High development cost and time for robotic systems
Lack of modularity and code reusability across projects
Low observability in real-time, mission-critical systems
Debugging concurrency issues like race conditions and deadlocks
Fragmentation in control, perception, and planning stacks
Barriers to deployment and scale for new robotics teams
business_model_focus: B2B platform infrastructure, robotics-as-a-service (RaaS) enablement, open-core dev tools, simulation + training data services, middleware licensing
market_opportunity: The global robotics market is projected to exceed $300B by 2032, but infrastructure remains a bottleneck. As robotic systems move from bespoke prototypes to scaled deployment, there is a growing need for reliable development tools, simulation platforms, and modular software foundations. Early-stage startups that power this transition — much like DevOps did for cloud software — have the opportunity to become critical infrastructure providers in the robotics economy.

thesis_name: Stablecoins: Emerging Global Payment Rail and Financial Platform
detailed_description: Stablecoins are evolving from niche crypto tools into foundational financial infrastructure. With transaction volumes surpassing Visa and Mastercard and a market cap reaching $250B in 2025, stablecoins are now a major force in payments and treasury management. Regulatory clarity, institutional adoption, and cross-border programmability have unlocked stablecoins’ utility as a superior alternative to legacy systems like SWIFT. These programmable digital assets offer instant, low-cost, 24/7 settlement, enabling new consumer and B2B financial services globally—from international payroll and remittances to merchant settlements and AI-driven agentic payments. The ecosystem now spans issuers, liquidity providers, orchestration platforms, and Web2.5 applications that abstract the crypto complexity to bring stablecoins into mainstream financial workflows.
core_problems_solved: High-cost, delayed settlement in cross-border payments
Lack of financial access in inflation-prone and underbanked markets
Operational inefficiencies due to prefunded accounts and trapped capital
Inaccessible digital dollar infrastructure for consumers and businesses
Slow, expensive B2B vendor payments and treasury operations
Limited liquidity and off-ramp coverage in emerging markets

example_companies.name: Brale
example_companies.description: Provides APIs for compliant stablecoin issuance and treasury operations, enabling businesses to create programmable, on-chain dollar infrastructure.

example_companies.name: BVNK
example_companies.description: Offers stablecoin payment orchestration, FX conversion, and compliance infrastructure for fintechs and global enterprises.

example_companies.name: OpenFX
example_companies.description: Builds FX and liquidity rails for stablecoin conversion and interoperability across emerging markets.

example_companies.name: DolarApp
example_companies.description: Enables Latin American users to save, spend, and transfer in USDC through a stablecoin-powered neobank experience.

example_companies.name: Modern Treasury + Brale
example_companies.description: Pioneers hybrid fiat and stablecoin rails for enterprise payments, offering APIs for programmable B2B treasury management.

example_companies.name: StableSea
example_companies.description: Provides liquidity infrastructure and conversion services to support stablecoin use in underbanked regions.

business_model_focus: B2B APIs, Payment Orchestration, Compliance-as-a-Service, Web2.5 Fintech Apps, Treasury Tools, FX Infrastructure
market_opportunity: The stablecoin market processed over $27T in volume last year and is on track to become the leading rail for cross-border payments, displacing legacy systems like SWIFT. With $4T+ of capital currently locked in prefunded accounts and increasing adoption by banks and corporates, stablecoins offer a vast opportunity for infrastructure providers, orchestration platforms, and Web2.5 applications that abstract crypto complexity and bring stablecoins into mainstream financial workflows. As issuers proliferate and stablecoins become native to enterprise treasury and consumer payments, the sector stands to reshape global finance.

detailed_description: Procurement, sourcing, and materials management remain stuck in legacy systems while the rest of the enterprise stack has modernized. Email, spreadsheets, and transactional ERP platforms still dominate workflows for supplier onboarding, material evaluation, and sourcing decisions. Yet the growing complexity of supply chains—from price volatility and geopolitical risk to compliance mandates and sustainability goals—demands upstream systems that are dynamic, data-rich, and interoperable. We believe this is a generational opportunity to re-platform how companies discover, evaluate, and integrate the materials they depend on.
core_problems_solved: Enable smarter sourcing decisions amid cost and supply volatility
Automate manual procurement workflows like onboarding and compliance
Improve visibility into supplier risk, material alternatives, and sustainability impact
Modernize procurement systems to integrate with engineering and operations
Support the shift toward circularity, reuse, and low-impact materials

example_companies.name: Copia
example_companies.description: A modern procurement system designed for industrial firms, streamlining sourcing, quoting, and supplier collaboration with a developer-first interface.

example_companies.name: Rheaply
example_companies.description: A circular procurement platform enabling companies to exchange and reuse physical assets, reducing waste and improving material utilization.

example_companies.name: Mason
example_companies.description: Procurement and product development platform helping consumer brands source, manage, and scale hardware and packaging components.

example_companies.name: Altana AI
example_companies.description: Builds a global supply chain knowledge graph to provide real-time visibility, compliance insights, and risk intelligence across suppliers.

example_companies.name: Sourcemap
example_companies.description: Supply chain transparency platform that helps companies trace the origin of materials and ensure compliance with ESG and sourcing regulations.

example_companies.name: Circularise
example_companies.description: Blockchain-based traceability platform that allows suppliers and brands to share sustainability data securely across complex supply chains.

business_model_focus: B2B SaaS, Platforms, Enterprise
market_opportunity: Enterprises spend trillions annually on materials and components, yet most sourcing decisions are made with limited visibility and outdated tools. As supply chains become more complex and sustainability regulations tighten, companies will need intelligent systems that improve sourcing decisions, compliance, and resilience. Startups that build dynamic procurement infrastructure—especially for regulated or material-intensive industries—stand to reshape how global production works.

thesis_name: The Promise of AI and Accounting
detailed_description: The accounting industry is experiencing a fundamental shift driven by two simultaneous forces: a growing talent crisis and the rise of AI automation. With over 17% of the CPA workforce exiting between 2021 and 2023 and a sharp decline in new CPA candidates, firms are turning to AI-powered solutions to maintain compliance, accuracy, and operational efficiency. LLMs and AI systems are increasingly capable of handling structured workflows such as data entry, categorization, reconciliation, document summarization, and anomaly detection. However, technical limitations around numerical reasoning, domain-specific judgment, and contextual understanding continue to present challenges, leaving room for innovation and improvement. The future of accounting lies in hybrid systems that combine intelligent automation with expert oversight, especially in the mid-market segment where adoption readiness meets complex needs.
core_problems_solved: Alleviate talent shortages in the accounting profession
Automate manual and error-prone accounting workflows
Increase efficiency in reconciliation and transaction categorization
Enable real-time financial reporting and audit readiness
Support compliance through anomaly detection and rule-based automation
Assist with interpreting complex documents and historical records

example_companies.name: Vic.ai
example_companies.description: An AI-powered platform for accounting automation, helping firms process invoices, approvals, and accounting workflows with minimal human input.

example_companies.name: Docyt
example_companies.description: Provides an AI-driven accounting automation platform for SMBs, including expense tracking, reconciliation, and real-time financial insights.

example_companies.name: Trullion
example_companies.description: Uses AI to analyze and automate lease accounting, revenue recognition, and audit workflows, offering transparency and compliance with accounting standards.

example_companies.name: Zeni
example_companies.description: Delivers AI-powered bookkeeping and CFO services for startups, using automation to manage cash flow, accounting, and financial planning.

example_companies.name: Indy
example_companies.description: An AI-enabled accounting and invoicing platform for freelancers and small business owners, offering tax prep, income tracking, and receipt management.

business_model_focus: B2B SaaS, SMB and Mid-Market Focus
market_opportunity: The U.S. accounting services market is valued at $145B, with over 46,000 CPA firms and 671,000 licensed CPAs. Amid a significant talent shortage and high attrition, firms are under pressure to adopt AI solutions. Platforms that build atomic infrastructure around real-time ledgering and expand into adjacent workflows stand to gain durable moats and high retention. Mid-market firms present a particularly attractive segment due to adoption readiness, compliance complexity, and larger budgets.

thesis_name: From RPA to Enterprise Agents: The New Era of Workflow Automation
detailed_description: Enterprise automation is entering a new paradigm as robotic process automation (RPA) evolves into intelligent, agentic workflows powered by large language models, computer vision, and dynamic reasoning. Traditional RPA systems—exemplified by UiPath, Blue Prism, and Automation Anywhere—were rule-based, expensive to implement, and brittle when underlying interfaces changed. Modern AI-native automation replaces these legacy systems with resilient, browser-based agents capable of understanding unstructured data, reading interfaces visually, and executing actions autonomously. These 'Enterprise Agents' integrate the deterministic structure of RPA with adaptive AI reasoning, allowing both horizontal low-code automation and deep vertical solutions across regulated industries such as healthcare, finance, and insurance. The next generation of automation will democratize agent creation for non-technical users while meeting the accuracy, compliance, and scalability demands of large enterprises.
core_problems_solved: Eliminate brittle and maintenance-heavy RPA systems
Automate complex workflows involving unstructured data and decision-making
Enable non-technical employees to create personalized automations
Bridge legacy and modern systems through browser-based orchestration
Increase scalability and resilience of enterprise workflows
Enhance compliance and reliability with hybrid AI + deterministic control

example_companies.name: Luminai
example_companies.description: Builds AI-powered browser agents for automating enterprise workflows, combining reasoning and visual interface understanding.

example_companies.name: Orby
example_companies.description: Develops 'large action models' that learn from user interactions to automatically generate workflow automations.

example_companies.name: Induced
example_companies.description: Offers an AI-native platform for dynamic process automation across industries such as finance and healthcare.

example_companies.name: Hebbia
example_companies.description: Provides vertical automation for financial services, using AI to extract insights and automate research workflows.

example_companies.name: Tennr
example_companies.description: Delivers healthcare automation agents that digitize faxes and streamline patient data retrieval and insurance workflows.

business_model_focus: B2B SaaS, Enterprise and Vertical Solutions
market_opportunity: The global RPA and enterprise automation market is projected to grow from $23 billion in 2024 to over $64 billion by 2034. As enterprises transition from rule-based RPA to adaptive AI agents, a massive replatforming cycle is underway. Horizontal platforms that democratize automation for non-technical users and vertical agents targeting regulated industries will capture the largest share of enterprise budgets. Winning companies will combine low-code usability with large action models, dynamic orchestration, and compliance-grade reliability.

thesis_name: The Next Era of Personal Finance: From Dashboards to Programmable Money
detailed_description: A generational and technological shift is transforming personal finance from static dashboards into adaptive, programmable systems. Over $84 trillion in wealth will transfer from Boomers to digital-native heirs who expect money to act on their behalf—intelligently, autonomously, and continuously. Legacy tools like Mint, Monarch, and Origin provided visibility but not agency: they tracked, but they didn’t act. The next wave of AI-native finance systems—powered by agentic reasoning, programmable ledgers, and real-time execution rails—will allow users to set personalized financial policies that self-optimize cash flow, yield, and spending in real time. These systems will unify context (real-time ledgers), cognition (agentic reasoning engines), and execution (programmable APIs and stablecoins) into a continuous, self-managing financial fabric. For a generation raised on personalized AI companions, this evolution from reactive dashboards to anticipatory finance is not just possible—it’s expected.
core_problems_solved: Eliminate manual financial management and static dashboards
Unify fragmented financial data across institutions into a real-time ledger
Automate decision-making and fund movement under user-defined rules
Bridge insight to action by turning advice into autonomous execution
Reduce human error and opportunity cost from idle or misallocated funds
Democratize access to intelligent financial systems for non-technical users

example_companies.name: Vibe Money
example_companies.description: Building a programmable-money assistant for Gen Z and Gen Alpha that negotiates, reallocates, and moves funds on behalf of users.

example_companies.name: Gaus
example_companies.description: An AI investing copilot that personalizes investment decisions based on user goals, constraints, and real-time market data.

example_companies.name: Dub
example_companies.description: Offers agentic investing tools that analyze market data and generate real-time investment insights for retail investors.

example_companies.name: Rocket Money
example_companies.description: Provides bill management and subscription optimization but represents the static generation of financial tools being disrupted.

example_companies.name: Monarch Money
example_companies.description: A modern personal finance dashboard—illustrative of today’s visualization-first approach that agentic systems aim to surpass.

business_model_focus: B2C and B2B2C SaaS, Subscription and Performance-Based Models
market_opportunity: Over $84 trillion in generational wealth will transition to digital-native users in the next two decades, alongside more than $1 trillion in annual U.S. consumer cash flows that remain unoptimized. As Gen Z and Gen Alpha adopt agentic finance, a new category of programmable money platforms will emerge—unifying budgeting, investing, bill management, and payments into continuous, autonomous systems. Early-stage companies that earn trust at the data layer and move from insights to action can define this category. The addressable opportunity spans asset management, deposit optimization, and real-time payments, collectively representing a trillion-dollar replatforming opportunity toward intelligent, autonomous finance.

thesis_name: AI in Autoimmune Drug Discovery: A Transformational Opportunity
detailed_description: Autoimmune diseases affect more than 10% of the global population and represent one of the largest unmet needs in modern medicine, with over 100 distinct diseases and a $180B+ market opportunity. Historically dominated by broad immunosuppressants and symptom-managing biologics, the field has lacked the precision tools and causal understanding that transformed oncology. That is now changing. A new generation of AI-native biotech platforms is redefining how autoimmune diseases are understood and treated—integrating single-cell and spatial multiomic data with large language and generative models to discover targets, stratify patients, and design therapies. These companies operate as virtual, AI-first entities, compressing discovery timelines from years to months by orchestrating CRO networks through autonomous agents and feedback loops. As biological foundation models mature and clinical validation accelerates, autoimmune drug discovery stands at the cusp of a platform revolution—one where precision immunology meets computational design.
core_problems_solved: Address the lack of targeted therapies across 100+ autoimmune diseases
Reduce early-stage drug development time by over 70%
Identify causal disease mechanisms and patient subpopulations via AI
Design and optimize multi-target biologics with higher efficacy and safety
Automate data curation, hypothesis generation, and IND preparation
Enable cost-efficient, virtual-first biopharma platforms with closed experimental loops

example_companies.name: Absci
example_companies.description: Integrates generative AI and synthetic biology to design and optimize protein-based therapeutics, accelerating discovery across immune and inflammatory diseases.

example_companies.name: Inceptive
example_companies.description: Develops foundation models for RNA and protein design, enabling new modalities for autoimmune and rare disease therapy.

example_companies.name: Nimbus Therapeutics
example_companies.description: Combines computational chemistry with immunology insights to target disease-driving pathways in autoimmunity and inflammation.

example_companies.name: CuraBio
example_companies.description: An emerging AI-native immunology platform leveraging multiomic data to discover and validate precision autoimmune drug targets.

example_companies.name: Genuity Science
example_companies.description: Uses population-scale genomic and clinical data with machine learning to identify causal variants and pathways in complex diseases including autoimmunity.

business_model_focus: AI-enabled platform biotech, Data Licensing, Strategic Partnerships, and Co-Development with Pharma
market_opportunity: The autoimmune therapeutics market is projected to exceed $180B by 2030, with over 100 diseases lacking effective targeted treatments. AI-native drug discovery platforms are compressing early-stage development timelines by up to 70%, from target discovery to IND readiness within 18–24 months. As single-cell and spatial omics datasets scale to tens of millions of patient-derived cells, and as generative models advance in protein and antibody design, precision immunology represents a once-in-a-decade opportunity to create category-defining biotech companies. The winners will combine proprietary immune datasets, generative model architectures, and CRO-orchestrated experimental feedback loops to unlock disease-modifying therapies across the autoimmune landscape.
